addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuror of England.

V
th
Sep
t
1592. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.215r
May it please yo
r
good L. I receaved
e last
of Au
g
at night, by
e post of
London,
her
Ma
ties
l
re
of
e 22 of
e same moneth, and one from yo
r
L. of
e 21. The 2 of Sep
t
I proposed to
the
states
e pointes of my charge: w
ch
they required
after of me, and I delivered them in writing:
wherof heereinclosed I have sent yo
w
e transcript.
In o
r
conference together they requested me solemnly,
as I tendered
e good estate of her Ma
tie
and the
contrey,
at I would signifie plainely to them, whe-
ther her Hig
nes
commaundement for embarking the
companies, were directed unto me in suche pe-
remptorie sort,
at it might not be delaied for a
litle longer time. Whereto in mine answear I
praied them to thinke,
at there was not any meanes,
to differ
e time in their behalf. They might al-
waies perceave it by her owne often writing, and
by
e effect of those messages
at I had delivered:
w
ch
were to signifie
at purpose, w
ch
is required,
at this present to be put in execution. And so I
desired
at they would understand it, and take
some order out of hand, whereby her Ma
tie
and
the contrey might be served w
t
content. And for
their further assurance of her full determination,
I offered them to reade
e letter sent unto me.
They would not seeme to put in doubt
e truth of
my speeche, and therfor sought not to see w
at
was
written unto me: but being greatly dismaied
went presently aside, and after communication
had among themselves, they declared unto me,
at if
e state of their army were knowen to her Ma
tie
fol.215v
considering howe muche it importeth her self,
they were sure she would be moved, to have her peo-
ple imploied, for
e time of
e siege. For
e castel
of
Coevoerden
was greatly distressed, and the
Enemie to relieve it had assembled all his strength,
and was encamped close unto it. If
e Englishe
were w
t
drawen, and
at supplie
at was required,
for
e garrison of
Berghen,
they should ether be con-
strained to dissolve their army p
nt
ly, or by seve-
ring of their forces, runne in danger of
e ruine
both of them and all
e rest. Besides it would
discredit
e course of all their actions, and give
occasion of murmur to
e commons of
e contrey,
who had yelded this sommer to a great deale greater
contribution, for an extraordinarie levie, then
they had ever done before, amounting at
e lest
to six score thousand poundes sterling: w
ch
would
all be cast away, and
e people discouraged to
doe
e like heereafter. And where it
might be supposed,
at their army all together, sur-
mounting every way
e nombers of
e Enemie,
might make a good retrait, it was
at w
ch
they
doubted most. For
e Enemies commanders were
muche to be respected, as men more sufficient,
and of greater experience, then
Count Maurice
had any. For defense of a sconce, or of a towne,
and for besieging of a place, and maintening a
skirmishe, they were well persuaded of their
service: but they thought
them
farre unable to marche
away in perfit sort, w
t
out geving to
e Enemie
any special advantage, and to range themselves
in
at order, as if
e Enemie should determine
fol.216r
to bidde them battel upon
e way, they might ans-
wear it in skill aswel as in courage. For these
occasions they pretended,
at
e letters of her Ma
tie
were wholy out of season, and therfor earnestly in-
treated,
at I would stay
e publication of the plea-
sure of her Hig
nes
and not certifie
S
r
Francis Vere
, till
they sawe a litle further, w
at
e enemie would at-
tempt. I had not muche to replie, in
respect of those dangers,
at they alleaged might en-
sue: but I declared unto them,
at they were al-
waies heeretofore, to presume
at
e Enemie would
rescue
e place: and before
at
e siege was begonne
by Count Maurice,
ei had knowledge from her Hig
nes
that she would send for
e companies:
at if any in-
convenience shall folowe therupon, by their comming
from
e Campe, they should blame themselves and
not her Ma
tie
who could no longer forslowe
e as-
sisting of
e
King,
aswell for her promise, as for
e urgent necessitie, wherunto he was reduced, and
they had reason to regard, no lesse then her self.
What her Ma
tie
would resolve, if she knowe their pre-
sent state, and heard their allegations, I could not
well conjecture, but for mine owne particular,
it was not left unto me, to doe as I would, and
therfore praied their assistance to
e accomplishing
of my charge. They knowe S
r
Francis Vere was
well affected to this contrey: he was nowe at
e
campe, and could judge by being present, if his
troupes might be spared, w
t
out their prejudice.
For if any suche mater were apparant unto him,
he would not be so wilfull, as to leave them in
extremitie, w
ch
he was sure would not stand w
t
her Ma
ties
good liking. The mater thus
fol.216v
debated w
t
speeches too and fro, when they sawe I
would not yelde, not to signifie to S
r
Francis her
Hig
nes
intent,
e whole assemblie was instant w
t
me, to refraine from sending to him, for no more but
2 daies longer: wherew
t
they thought they might
be steeded, for
at
e Enemie was so neere, and had a
purpose, as it seemed, and as Coevoerden required,
to essay o
r
forces to
e uttermost. Their
importunitie was so great, as to so smalle a dem
a
de,
w
ch
I hoped would not hinder her Ma
tie
designes,
and I perceaved might availe to satisfie their mindes
I was contented to assent, and promise not to
write, till
at 2 daies were expired, to S
r
Francis Vere:
wherew
t
her Ma
tie
, I trust, will be nothing displeased,
if yo
r
L. will vouchesafe, to thinke
e best of my pro-
ceeding. We had intelligence to day,
w
ch
is
e second of
e two,
at they desired at my
handes,
at Coevoerden hath compounded: wherof I
have written this morning unto yo
w
, by a fitte op-
portunitie, w
ch
was offered me to send by one
at
went for
Zeland.
I have bin also w
t
e states,
to hasten their answear to her Ma
ties
demaundes,
and especially to
at w
ch
concerned
e companies,
declaring plainely to them,
at I was minded this
evening to dispatche unto S
r
Francis. They
signifie therupon
at they will presently resolve,
and will sette it downe in writing, aswell for
that mater, as for
e rest
at I proposed, concer-
ning
Britaine,
Ostend,
and
e 18 Canoniers, and
send it me to day, or to morowe at
e furthest.
Whiche when I have receaved I will joine with
this letter, and send it to yo
r
L. But if they
happen to delay me, I will send away this l
re
and convey their answear when it comes. W
ch
I
fol.217r
doe make full account, about the mater of the
companies, will be altogether negative. And yet
as farre as I perceave, by
e maner of their dealing
and by
e opinion of others, they will not lette their
passage. Howsoever they doe determine I will
write this night to S
r
Francis Vere, and send
e copies
of those letters,
at I have receaved, and
e letter
unto him from my LL. of
e Councel: whiche will
cause him, I am sure, to come away fourth with:
and assoone as he is come,
e directions sent
unto us from my LL. of
e Councel,
e 1 of July last,
shall be folowed very thorowly.
I have moved
M
r
Caron
, as yo
r
L. hath willed,
to assist me in my suite, to have
e companies
away, w
t
e liking of
e contrey. He wanteth
no good will, to doe his best in
at behalf, but no
doubt it is so, as he himself doth affirme, that it is
not for him w
t
this people, to make
at motion for her
Ma
tie
. For considering their bent, he shall but pur-
chase an opinion of partiallitie in his dealing, and
prevaile by no persuasion. I can not learne
by any meanes, to report upon knowledge, for w
at
occasion he was sent for. To my understanding
at w
ch
he doth pretend, about his privat estate, is
farre from
e mater. For I am still of
at opini
o
,
as when I writte unto yo
r
L.
e 20 of
e last.
Of
e strength of
e companies,
at are w
t
S
r
Francis, as I have formerly advertised, the
rolles were consigned, about
e 10 day of Au
g
to
the handes of
S
r
Thomas Wilkes
,
e musters being
taken
e 8 and 15 of July. I have sent heerein-
closed
e Abbreviat of them: having taken further
order,
at
M
r
Allen
e Commissary shall presently
fol.217v
calle a muster, when S
r
Francis is returned:
From
e Campe we heare no more, but
at
e 2 of
this moneth,
Verdugo
w
t
his forces being fast by
e
[ Cor. Verde ]
Castell, it was surrendred to Count Maurice, having
made their composition, to depart w
t
bagge and
baggage, and enseignes disploied. There were
said to marche away about
e nomber of 500.
500
It is advertised from neutral places,
at are neere
unto
e Enemie,
at in
e attempt w
ch
ei gave
e
28 of
e last, to enter o
r
trenches, there were at
e lest 400 slaine, and were all recovered by
e
Enemie, and caried away, unles it were a 100
whiche were killed in
e trenches. Of o
rs
there
was one man onely slaine, and six others hurt, of
w
ch
Count William
was one being shotte a thwart
e belly, but w
t
out any danger. Wheras we have
bin told,
at
Count Charles Mansfield
, and
Mondrag
o
were there in person, it seemeth by
e occurrences,
w
ch
come from neutral places,
at they are not with
Verdugo.
and thus I take my humble leave.
At
e Hage. Sep
t
4 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
fol.218r
I have kept this letter a day longer, expecting
when
e states would send me their answear.
But because I doe perceave, it will not be today,
and my messenger is ready to carie this presently,
I thought I should doe best, to send yo
w
this
before, and after their answear, assoone as I re-
ceave it.
Sep
t
5 1592.
